ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

ECONOMIC RESTRUCTURING SHARES


    1. Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance if the Ministry can consider (i) extending the deadline for the 128,000 persons who missed out on the Economic Restructuring Shares (ERS); (ii) providing some measures to reach out to this group of people; and (iii) assisting them with their top ups if they are in financial difficulties or have some other compelling reasons for being unable to do so.

    2. Mr Gan Kim Yong asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance whether his Ministry will consider waiving the $50 contribution to the Central Provident Fund (CPF) required to qualify for the Economic Restructuring Shares (ERS) in instances where the recipient is facing financial difficulties.

    3. Dr Lily Neo asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance, in view of the large number of 128,000 persons who missed out on the Economic Restructuring Shares (ERS), will the Government consider extending the deadline for this group and waiving the $50 top-up in the Central Provident Fund (CPF) for those with financial difficulties.

Column: 2151



    4. Mr Loh Meng See asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (a) what are the reasons for a sizeable number of more than 100,000 citizens not topping up their CPF to benefit from the new Economic Restructuring Shares; (b) what is the profile of these citizens and why are they having difficulty to top up; and (c) will the Government be able to give them another chance to benefit from the scheme.

    5. Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance if he will (i) give a breakdown of the profile of the 128,000 Singaporeans who missed out on the Economic Restructuring Shares (ERS); (ii) inform the House whether additional efforts are being made to reach out to these people and help them with the top-up, if needed; and (iii) state whether the unallocated money from the ERS will be channelled to provide more aid to the poor and needy.

    The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (Mr Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Speaker, Sir, with your permission, I will answer Questions 1-5 together.

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    Mr Lee Hsien Loong: The ERS is part of the offset package to help Singaporeans adjust to the increase in the GST rate. It covers the net increase in tax for nearly every Singaporean for at least 5 years. There is no question of the offset not being adequate for this purpose.

    Based on the latest data from CPF Board, about 100,336 Singaporeans, or about 5% of the total of 2.18 million eligible Singaporeans, did not contribute $50 into their CPF accounts by 31st December 2002. This is lower than the earlier reported figure of 128,000, which was not the final count, as last minute contributions were still being processed by CPF Board.

    The detailed breakdown is in the table (Cols. 2273 - 2274) that I have circulated to Members, and

Column: 2152

you should find it on your seats. The highest rates of non-participation came from those staying in welfare homes and 1-room HDB flats. The rate for those in 2-room HDB flats was also rather high. There were 9,791 of such cases in all (in other words, welfare homes, 1-rooms and 2-rooms). They account for about 13% of the total number of eligible Singaporeans in these categories, but only 0.5% of the total number of eligible Singaporeans. This is the relatively small group that we should focus on.
Annex - Singaporeans who did not qualify for ERS (Cols. 2273 - 2274)


    The Government has put in considerable effort to remind Singaporeans to top up their CPF accounts by 31st December 2002 to qualify for the ERS. In August 2002, CPF Board sent letters to all Singaporeans to inform them of the ERS Scheme and to remind those who had not yet topped up to do so as soon as possible. In November and December 2002, MOF and CPF Board issued press releases, and ran radio trailers and newspaper advertisements. We mobilised the grassroots organisations (GROs). The grassroots organisations not only put up reminder posters at HDB void decks, but made house visits to those staying in 1- to 3-room HDB flats. If the occupants were not in, they made repeat visits; sometimes three or four times. If the residents could not afford the $50, the grassroots organisations helped them financially on a case-by-case basis.

    There could be many reasons why people did not top up their CPF accounts in time. Some may have forgotten, others may have been overseas. There may even have been some who were not interested in the shares. The grassroots leaders who made the house visits have reported that a significant proportion of those who had not topped-up their CPF accounts could not be found at the addresses given. Conceivably, they had not updated their addresses on their NRICs with the National Registration Office and hence, would not have received information about the ERS scheme posted to them.

Column: 2153



    Among the lower income households, especially the older folks, many of those who did not top up probably did not have active CPF accounts. They may have found it difficult to top up their accounts, even though help from the GROs was available. Some may not have understood how the scheme would help them.

    Mr Gan Kim Yong and Dr Lily Neo have asked to waive the $50 CPF top-up requirement for those with financial difficulties. Let me explain the purpose of the $50 contribution. Besides encouraging Singaporeans to maintain an active CPF account that helps provide for their retirement, the top-up is a way for Singaporeans to show that they are doing something to receive their ERS. It is really to put up your hand and say, "I'm here. I would like to participate in the scheme". It is not desirable for the Government simply to give the shares to all Singaporeans, without even knowing where he is or whether he wants the shares. For example, the person may have emigrated, and may not have maintained his links with Singapore. Why should we give it to him?

    Dr Lily Neo, Mr Loh Meng See and Dr Amy Khor have asked if the Government will give those who missed out another chance to benefit from the scheme. For those who are not poor, and these form the majority of those who did not top up, I think we should respect their decision not to participate in the scheme. The Government made them an offer, they decided not to take it up, and we should leave the matter there. We have to be fair to the 95% of Singaporeans who took the trouble to top up by the deadline, some of them queuing up to do so on the last day. If each time the Government sets a deadline, it gets extended because people did not make the effort to meet it, soon the Government's terms and statements will not be taken seriously.

    However, for the lower income groups, ie, the 9,791 cases of 1-roomers, 2-roomers and people in welfare homes, I agree fully with the MPs that we should be flexible and make a further effort to

Column: 2154

reach them. They are the ones most likely to have had genuine financial difficulties and to have been unable to make alternative arrangements. They are the most in need of the ERS shares. The Government will therefore make a special arrangement to help them.

    We will give all the Advisors to the grassroots organisations the list of residents staying in 1- and 2-room HDB flats, and welfare homes, who have not topped up their CPF. The grassroots organisations will get in touch with them and make arrangements for them to participate in the ERS scheme, extending financial help where necessary. As the numbers are not too many, it should be feasible for us to take this more personalised approach. The special facility will be provided up to 31st March 2003, to give the grassroots organisations sufficient time to identify and reach out to those in need.

    Mr Steve Chia asked whether the unallocated money from the ERS will be channelled to provide more aid to the poor and needy. The special arrangement I have just mentioned will help some more needy Singaporeans get their ERS. The rest of the ERS money will remain in the ERS Fund, and become available for future ERS distributions. The ERS Fund is set up as a private trust fund specifically to distribute ERS shares. The Government has many other schemes to help the poor and needy who require assistance.

    For future lots of ERS, we are considering possible ways to be more flexible with the CPF contribution requirement, especially for the lower-income, the elderly, and Singaporeans staying in welfare homes. My Ministry is studying the options. We have time as the next contribution is not due until 31st December 2003.

    Dr Lily Neo (Jalan Besar): May I ask the Deputy Prime Minister whether he would consider the extension of the ERS CPF top-ups to 3-room HDB dwellers as well, as there are residents in the 3-room HDB

Column: 2155

flats who also require assistance from the grassroots and the MPs?

    Could I also ask whether it is a fair proposal for the Community Development Council to come up with matching funds in the respective constituencies to help those residents who have financial difficulties in their CPF top-ups?

    Mr Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, first, on the 3-roomers. I think we have to draw the line somewhere. If I had drawn the line at the 3-roomers, I think Dr Neo would have asked me for the 4-roomers. But, nevertheless, there will be cases where 3-roomers will have financial problems. And if MPs come across any such cases and write in to the CPF Board, the Board will consider them sympathetically.

    As for using the CDC's money to match, perhaps we should remember that the CDC's money actually came from the Government in the first place. But I am sure the Member will have sources of funds and that the CDC has arranged for donations and wants to use those donations for this purpose, that would be very helpful.

    Ms Braema Mathiaparanam (Nominated Member): Sir, two supplementary questions, please. As regards those who have been helped with the $50 through the CCC's visits, could we know the number of people who have been helped, because they could not even afford the $50? The other question that I have is on the almost 10,000 people - the 1-roomers, 2-roomers and residents of welfare homes. The Deputy Prime Minister spoke about arrangements. What exactly are these arrangements? And if they do not have $50, is it possible to help them in other ways?

    Mr Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not have the exact number of how many were given $50 by the grassroots organisations, because these were arrangements made by the individual

Column: 2156

Advisors. But I am assured that the Advisors have gone through it and wherever people needed assistance and could not afford the $50, it has been forthcoming. I do not think the number is very large. I believe they would number in a few hundreds.

    As for what exactly the arrangements will be for the 10,000 which we are talking about now, I leave that to the Advisors. I have discussed it with them, particularly the Advisors from the constituencies which have larger concentrations of the poor and older folks, like Dr Lily Neo in Kreta Ayer and a few others who have smaller flats and older residents. And they assured me that the financing is not a problem. The question is: does the person want to participate and is it really a problem that he is unable to find the $50? If it is, we can make the arrangements for him. Because if you just look at it, 10,000 people times $50, it is $500,000; divided by 80 Advisors, it is about $6,000 per Advisor. It is not an enormous amount of money. It can be arranged.

    Mr Heng Chee How (Jalan Besar): Sir, in the review that the Ministry of Finance is conducting for future ERS, I would like to ask the Deputy Prime Minister whether he would consider lowering the quantum from $50 to something less, eg, $10, for this particular exercise. The groups that have the highest disqualification rates are actually the lower income. After all, everybody who qualifies could actually draw out their $50 the day after receiving their ERS.

    Mr Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, we will consider all possibilities. I think for the older folks, we can be much more flexible. Because as Mr Heng Chee How has pointed out, once you pay the money in, you are entitled to draw it out the next day. But for the younger people, they are not entitled to draw it out the next day. When they reach the age of 55, then they can take it out together with the rest of their CPF money. So I think there is a point. And to put in $50 in order to collect $400 or more from the Government is not an unreasonable request.

PROFITEERING


    6. Mr Gan Kim Yong asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance whether there have been significant incidents of profiteering arising from the revision of the Goods and Services Tax (GST) to 4% from 1st January 2003 and if so, what actions have been taken so far in dealing with these incidents.

    The Minister of State, Prime Minister's Office (Mr Chan Soo Sen) (for the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance): Sir, there appears to have been no significant incidents of profiteering so far. Anyway, conditions for profiteering are not present. There is no shortage of goods in the market. Retailers are trying their best to retain customers through competitive pricing. Consumers have many choices and can turn from one retailer to another. We have investigated a few items which have increased in price and we found that the increases cannot be attributed solely to the increase in GST.

    The Committee Against Profiteering, which I am chairing, was set up to deal with profiteering and unjustified price increases. From 1st December 2002 to 20th January 2003, the Committee received a total of 47 reports. The majority related to price increases of food items as well as cooked food items.

    Of these, 29 were found not to be due to profiteering on account of GST increases. Replies have been given to these respondents. Nine have been forwarded to the respective Constituency Committee Against Profiteering for further investigation, and the investigation is still in progress. Four have been forwarded to the Consumers Association of Singapore (CASE) for review. The Committee Against Profiteering is currently looking into the remaining five unresolved reports.

    If consumers come across any instances of businesses trying to profiteer from the GST increase, they should provide feedback to the Committee by filling in the forms which are available in all community centres, community clubs as well as our website.

FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE BY STUDENTS


    7. Mr Gan Kim Yong asked the Minister for Education (a) how many students have approached his Ministry for financial assistance for the year 2003; (b) how many have been granted such assistance; and (c) whether there has been a significant increase in the number of students seeking the assistance compared to previous years.

    The Senior Minister of State for Education (Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, as at 18th January 2003, schools have processed and approved 6,555 applications for the Ministry of Education Financial Assistance Scheme (FAS) which grants waiver of school fees and part of the miscellaneous fees, and provides free textbooks to students. In year 2002, a total of 7,387 students received help from the MOE Financial Assistance Scheme. 2002 saw a significant increase in approved MOE financial assistance cases compared to 5,332 cases approved in year 2001.

    The income criteria for the MOE Financial Assistance Scheme are pegged to MCDS' Public Assistance scheme. In line with the revision in MCDS' Public Assistance rates with effect from January this year, the Ministry of Education has also reviewed and raised the income criterion for the MOE Financial Assistance Scheme. From 2nd January this year, a citizen student would be eligible for the MOE Financial Assistance Scheme if the family's gross income per month does not exceed $900 for families with one or two children, and $1,050 for families with three or more children. Before the revision, the income ceiling was $775 for families with one or two children and $900 for families with three or more children.

    Students can approach the schools for financial assistance at any time during the year. For all financial assistance applications received, schools will first assess the student's eligibility for the MOE Financial Assistance Scheme. If the students are not eligible or need additional financial assistance, schools will help to source for

Column: 2159

support from other sources, eg, the financial assistance schemes administered by the School Advisory/Management Committees (SAC/SMC) and community organisations like the Community Development Councils and voluntary welfare organisations. No child is denied an education on account of financial difficulties.

MEDISAVE
(Use for dormiciliary medical and nursing care)


    8. Dr Chong Weng Chiew asked the Minister for Health in the light of increased emphasis on step-down services, will his Ministry allow the use of Medisave to pay for dormiciliary medical and nursing care.

    The Minister for Health (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, first, I wish to reiterate that Medisave is primarily intended for inpatient hospitalisations. However, over the years, the Ministry of Health has allowed the use of Medisave for day surgeries and certain expensive treatments, which were originally inpatient treatment but are now carried out more effectively as outpatient treatments, such as renal dialysis and chemotherapy for cancer patients. However, the Ministry does not intend to allow Medisave to be used for dormiciliary medical and nursing care, so that individuals can preserve their Medisave for the more expensive medical treatments.

    From 1st October 2002, the Ministry of Health has extended Government subsidies to eligible elderly Singaporeans who require home medical and home nursing services so that they can afford such services. Out-of-pocket expenditure is kept low, at between $30-$60 per home medical visit and $13-$28 per home nursing visit, after the 50% to 75% subsidy from the Government. Those who are severely disabled and covered under ElderShield or IDAPE Scheme can also receive cash payments of $300 per month from ElderShield, or up to $150 per month

Column: 2160

from IDAPE Scheme. These would further help them pay for their home medical and home nursing services.

    Dr Chong Weng Chiew (Tanjong Pagar): There are two principles of home medical and home nursing care. One, it actually gives convenience to the patient as well as providing holistic approach to patient care. The second point is that with home medical and home nursing, it is one of the ways to decrease health expenditure. And the fact that Singapore is moving towards an ageing population ----

    Mr Speaker: What is your question, Dr Chong?

    Dr Chong Weng Chiew: Home medical is one of the roots which can avoid hospitalisation for patients. Thus, with this change of trend of hospitalisation, can we not use Medisave for home medical and home nursing?

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: As I have explained earlier, medical treatments are very expensive. We are asking Singaporeans to save 6% of their income in Medisave and therefore we have to make use of our Medisave correctly. The policy of Medisave is to target this saving at the more expensive medical treatments, which is largely the inpatient care. Over the years, we have extended it to some outpatient care which is very expensive too. But so far, we have not allowed Medisave to be used for GP care, for step-down care, home medical and home nursing care. And I think these are very sensible reasons. Because if we allow Medisave to be used for GP care, for home nursing and home medical, very soon you will not have very much Medisave left for your hospitalisation care.

    Last year, we made an exception. We recognised that home medical and home nursing care for the very severely disabled will cost a lot of money, and that is the reason why we introduced ElderShield and allowed Singaporeans to use up to 1% of their Medisave if they insure themselves under ElderShield. And if they are severely disabled, the group insurance

Column: 2161

that they participate in will help pay for their home medical and home nursing. So we are already making an extension of using the Medisave for the severely disabled who need home medical, home nursing or institutional nursing care. But if we extend Medisave to all kinds of home medical and home nursing, then your 6% Medisave contribution will not be enough. If the Member can convince other Members of this House to raise the Medisave contribution from 6% to 8%, then I am prepared to consider extending it.

    Dr Lily Neo: May I ask the Minister what has his Ministry done to improve dormiciliary step-down services, especially in patient care and in the training of personnel? And does he agree that this is an important area to develop in view of the demographic profile?

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: I agree entirely with the Member. I think home medical and home nursing are critical components of our step-down care infrastructure. Over the last two years, for example, we have put in place what we designate as approved providers - nursing homes, community hospitals - who can extend home medical and home nursing services. We are trying to build up such services, not just by specialised home medical and home nursing services like the Home Nursing Foundation, but also extend the provision by other groups - nursing homes, community hospitals - so that these become more readily available. Recently, I announced that the Ministry is extending training grants for step-down care, not just professionals in the community hospitals and nursing homes, but also people extending home medical and home nursing services. So, we recognise that this is a very important area. It is a very manpower intensive area, despite Singapore being a small island. If we have a nurse visiting homes, there is a very limited number of visits she can make every day. So it is a very expensive service. But we recognise that this is an important service because it helps to keep the elderly in the community, in the home, and we intend to build this up.

EXPULSION OF STUDENTS
(Statistics and guidelines)


    9. Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan asked the Minister for Education (a) how many students, by levels, were expelled from schools for each year from 2000 to 2002; (b) whether these numbers had been increasing over the years; (c) what are the current guidelines provided by the Ministry to school principals regarding the expulsion of students; (d) what help and counselling these students are given or can turn to before and after expulsion; and (e) whether the Ministry can provide clear guidelines and assistance for their re-admission to schools, instead of asking the students and their parents to apply directly to the schools.

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of students expelled at the primary level was 0 in year 2000, three in year 2001 and four in year 2002. For the secondary level, the statistics were 118 in 2000, 164 in 2001 and 94 in 2002. At the pre-university level, it was six in 2000 and none in 2001 and 2002.

    The number of students expelled at the primary level has remained small over the last three years, and I should clarify that out of the four who were expelled in year 2002, two of them were really drop-out cases who had Malaysian parents and went back to Malaysia. They have been technically classified as expulsion cases because of absenteeism but they are really drop-out cases. For the secondary and pre-university levels, there has been a falling trend. This can be attributed to the measures put in place by schools, junior colleges and centralised institutes to instill good discipline in their students and to sustain their interest in schooling.

    A student is expelled if he commits a very serious offence such as assault, and if allowing him to remain would threaten the safety of other students or undermine school discipline. There are also some cases of expulsion on account of persistent absenteeism. Expulsion is only

Column: 2163

done as a last resort when measures such as counselling, suspension and other disciplinary measures have had no effect on improving the student's conduct or discipline. The Ministry does not have a set of guidelines on expulsion which principals have to follow. The principal has the full authority to decide on the expulsion of recalcitrant students. The principal is in the best position to decide when a student should be removed from the school for serious misdemeanours so as to maintain discipline and good order for the safety and welfare of all students in the school.

    Schools take a proactive approach to ensure that students remain interested in schooling. The proactive measures that schools adopt include pastoral care, life-skills and career guidance programmes which are aimed at helping students build self esteem, take responsibility for their own actions and develop purposefulness in life. Each school has in place a formal structure involving the Principal, Vice-Principal and teacher counsellors, together with external agencies, such as the self-help groups and family service centres to counsel and assist students with behavioural problems.

    The intervention measures that schools adopt include counselling the students with the involvement of the parents. Schools also work quite closely with the parents.

    Dr Amy Khor also asked about readmission to schools. Students who have been expelled can be readmitted to another school. Having students apply directly to the new school for readmission is part of the process of helping them turn over a new leaf. In personally seeking readmission to the new school, the student will have the chance to explain why he is deserving of a second chance. The student will have to give an undertaking to his new principal that he would take personal responsibility for his conduct and attitude. Let me just take Members back to life in September 1964, ie, about a year and a half after I was born,

Column: 2214

    This was the headline in the Straits Times of 22nd July 1964:

    "Singapore curfew after clashes. The Acting Prime Minister, Tun Abdul Razak, made an appeal for calm in a broadcast tonight on the clashes which occurred in Singapore, to which 74 people were killed and about 178 injured, leading to the imposition of a curfew from 9.30 pm to 6.00 am.

Column: 2215

    Just like the fundamentalist groups who reject everything Western without a clear understanding, we find today such thinking permeating the Muslim mind in a variety of ways. To those who view the world as incompatible with their version of religion, they would see people who advocate a multitude of voices and interpretations of the religion as being the enemy. Their insistence on a monolithic interpretation of Islam, with no room for disagreement, must necessarily clash with those who advocate diversity. Hence, we see groups issuing edicts of death to those who advocate a different view from them. We must collectively reject these views immediately.

    The best safeguard we can put in place is to allow a diversity of views and opinions to emerge. Muslims all over the world will never have disputes on the fundamental principles of Islam, such as the oneness of God, the Prophecy of Muhammad, the five daily prayers, the payment of wealth tax, and fasting. But in the way we order our lives, cherish our women, organise our religious life, exist in a multi-religious society, educate our young, and so on, there can be differences. Of course, the diversity cannot be unlimited. Certainly, if some advocate violence as a basis of their struggle, then we must all condemn it. As rightly pointed out by several Muslim scholars, the proper interpretation of Islam is compatible with democracy and human rights. The Way Forward - Building the Good Society

    Sir, Islam encourages all Muslims to build the good society. Elements of the good society include a system to protect weaker members of society, measures to insure a corruption-free environment, the establishment of a safe and secure environment, the provision of opportunities for everyone to grow and develop, a good health care system, and an economic system that promotes development for all in that society. Our contribution to Singapore must be to help build this good society. In fact, I would argue that elements of the good society exist in Singapore, and that it is our duty as good Muslims and good Singaporeans to protect this.

    Hence, I am encouraged by the achievements of Ms Misnati Dollah and Mr Zainul Sarib who are among the winners of the National Productivity Award for the year 2002 in Singapore. In their own quiet ways, they are helping to promote the productivity movement, which is central to an efficient economic system. They, like many other Malay/Muslim workers in Singapore, are building the good society in Singapore. Our meritocratic system has also allowed us to identify talented Malays for key appointments on the boards of statutory bodies and Government-related agencies. And we have been doing this for a very long time, ever since your days as Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs, Sir. So, today, we find Malays on the boards of organisations, such as the Public Service Commission, MPA, CAAS, LTA, Science Centre, MDA, National Heritage Board and the Singapore Management University.

    There are many other ways in which Muslims can contribute to the building of the good society. The BBC reported last week on the discovery by a group of US researchers in the fight against cholera. Using old sari material folded four times as a filter for river water, they found that they could cut down the incidence of cholera by half among villagers in Bangladesh. I traced the report and found that one of the researchers is a Muslim from Bangladesh who is currently working in

Column: 2241

Maryland with other non-Muslim scientists on this project. I communicated with him, and he told me that he and his colleagues have been working for 27 years in a search for a cure for cholera among poor villagers. As a Muslim, Professor Anwar Huq is contributing to the good society.

    As various Members of the House have pointed out, the current challenges present a window of opportunity for Singaporeans to stand up to defend the society we want to preserve and build upon. Muslims and non-Muslims in Singapore have a role to play in ensuring that the good society prevails. Apart from the need to reach out to one another and to strengthen our social cohesion and community bonding, it is also necessary for us to encourage good behaviour and contributions from each other. By expanding our common space through the encouragement of the adoption of healthy common values, such as the respect for diversity, a commitment to securing peace and harmony for Singapore, a determination to build a strong economy, a desire to provide assistance to the weaker members of society, and to provide a safe and secure environment, all Singaporeans will surely contribute to the good society. It is by ensuring that we all, Muslims and non-Muslims, work together towards the common good that we can ensure a peaceful and harmonious, cohesive and resilient Singapore.

    Sir, the threat of terrorism is a complex challenge. Our efforts at strengthening our social cohesion must continue with renewed vigour and focus. Everyone must understand that he or she has a role to play, be it in schools, workplaces, recreational centres, and even in places of worship.

    But I would also argue that the solution to this problem lies more in the hands of those with the power to effect meaningful change. Those in leadership positions, in whichever organisations or institutions that they belong to, play a key role in this fight against terrorism. If we fail to

Column: 2242

diagnose and understand this phenomenon correctly, then we risk the well-being of our nation. Simplistic analysis of the global terrorism threat and distorted views of history and of contemporary Muslim societies and countries serve only to confuse and detract from real understanding. Fashionable ideas of the clash of different religious communities as the outcome of modern history are no different from the views of the fundamentalists who divide the world into two opposing ethical communities. Such ideas give fodder to the fundamentalist mind. We should not give space for such ideas here in Singapore. When the Government fought the Communists and the communalists, it was the call to, and support for, of those within the Chinese community who were committed to the idea of a modern and multi-racial Singapore, to stand up against such elements, that helped win the day. Similarly, today we should give notice to those who are prepared to use religious sentiments to provoke resentment towards the State or any other group, that they will suffer the wrath of the people and the State. Such elements are destructive to our nation-building effort and should never be allowed to grow. Space and support should be given to the progressive elements in the Malay/Muslim community.

    This is a struggle for the hearts and minds of our people. The path of moderation and tolerance is the only way for Singapore to survive as a nation. Terror of any kind, and carried out by any group, will bring great harm. We must engender in our people the spirit that is constructive towards our nation building effort. This is the spirit that was seen in Whampoa recently when a fire broke out near a lift-landing and a couple was trapped inside the lift. A Malay family living closest to the lift-landing rallied other neighbours to assist the couple. It was the same spirit that drove my late father and other villagers, both Chinese and Malays, to form watch groups to protect our kampong during the 1964 riots. It is this spirit that supports the common good that is needed now.

    Yesterday, when the Minister was talking about the inconveniences suffered by the Chinese-educated at that time, it stirred up my memory of all those restriction orders, banned books, banned movies, banned songs, etc. Bit by bit, the world map then was being painted red -- the Soviet Union was red, China was red, and many other countries were turning red. It was feared then that the whole world was turning red, but it turns out now that the real world is technicolour. It will not turn totally green as the terrorists would want it to be.

    The present-day terrorism is global and borderless. In the past, when technology and transportation were not so

Column: 2257

advanced, the communists then and terrorists now are different. The communists at that time were localised, and not cross-bordered. That was why we had then the Malayan Communists, the Vietnamese Communists, the Indian Communists, the Burmese Communists, the Chinese Communists and so on. There were no Singapore Communists, because Singapore and Malaya were one same territory at that time.

    Like the new economy, terrorism has been brought to a higher plane by the development in technology and transportation. They have become global and borderless. Otherwise, the JI members would have to take years before they could go to Afghanistan and back. In the Tang Dynasty, when the High Priest Tipitaka went from China to India to get the sutra, he met with a lot of difficulties and danger. If not for his three skilful and resourceful disciples who were armed with supernatural power, he would not have succeeded.

    I support the Government's recommendations in the White Paper for a three-fold counter measures against the terrorist threat: (1) Enhancing security measures; (2) Policing the spread of terrorist and extremist ideology; and (3) Strengthening social cohesion and religious harmony.

    I would like to present my view on enhancing security and strengthening unity.

    In enhancing security, the problem we have is that the sense of crisis of our people is not strong enough. Let me illustrate: In order to enhance security, the Police has put up barricade at night-spots to be ready for all eventualities. But, we receive complaints from the business community that this has affected their business. Some feel that they are being inconvenienced as parking was made difficult. No doubt, we want business, but do they want their lives? We want to counter terrorism, and we need also to prevent terrorism. Only then can we be safe and sound.

    Another example is the SIA's $288 package to Bali attracted more than 20,000

Column: 2258

people during the school holiday month. SIA's Bali package was our show of support for Indonesia. It also served to boost the outside world's confidence in Indonesia. Why did so many people want to go to Bali? Some people told me that the most dangerous place was actually the safest place. However, there were only some who thought that many people went there simply because Bali was the cheapest destination. We could visit the place, but the question is with what frame of mind do we go there. In my view, we can visit Bali to support its tourism industry, and at the same time to appreciate the danger of terrorism. This is killing two birds with one stone. We should not be going there simply because it is "cheap, cheap"!

    In order to enhance unity among the various ethnic groups, the IRCC and Harmony Circles should place more emphasis on dispelling the mutual suspicion among the communities. The mutual visits to the places of worship is just a warming-up exercise. What we should really do is to cultivate the spirit of comrade-in-arms to face difficulties togther, and not to suspect each other when problems arise.

    There was a small debate between the Member for Hougang and Mr Hawazi. There was some complaint that some Chinese employers persisted in employing only workers who could speak Mandarin. From the dialogue sessions I conducted for the Feedback Unit, I observed that employers were more concerned with the working capability of the workers during the recruitment process than the colour of their skin. If the ability to speak Mandarin is a necessity for the job, it would naturally become a pre-requisite that the successful applicant must speak Mandarin. As such, I would urge our Malay compatriots to learn Mandarin as a kind of skill.

    Let me give you another example. I know of a Malay worker in Koh Brothers Limited, whose father was also an employee there. His boss is a Chinese and they get along very well. The Chinese boss would speak Malay to the Malay employee, and the Malay employee would

Column: 2259

speak to his Chinese boss in Teochew. I asked him how he picked up Teochew and whether it was hard to learn. He replied to me in Teochew, "Tieh gu jiu wei (Listen more and you will know)!" I think we should look at this matter in this light, then there should be no problem.

    Another example is my recent visit to Turkey. I was visiting the bazaar in Istanbul when a shopkeeper came up to me and spoke to me smilingly in Mandarin, "Huan ying, huan ying! Qing jin lai canguan (Welcome, welcome. Please come in and look around)! Hen pianyi, hen pianyi (Very cheap, very cheap)!" In the past, whenever I went overseas, especially in Europe and the United States, I would be taken as a Japanese, and the shopkeepers would greet me "Irashaimase (Welcome)" in Japanese. Nowadays, there are lots of Mainland Chinese tourists visiting Hong Kong, European and Asian countries, including Singapore, and they are big spenders. So now, I am being looked upon as a Chinese. These are market forces!

    Nowadays, jobs are hard to come by, and this is due to recession, coupled with the fact that many companies are relocating and many jobs were lost. Our Malay compatriots have problem finding jobs, so have the Mandarin-speaking Chinese compatriots! This is the problem. We should look at the problem in the proper prospective.

    As such, I suggest we enhance the unity among our various ethnic groups by clarifying all these misconceptions to avoid mutual suspicion and mistrust. That is the important thing to do.

    I support the motion.

    Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Mdm Deputy Speaker, I would like to speak in support of the motion from three aspects, namely, why the need for a White Paper on the JI threat, the White Paper itself and what are the desired responses to the Singapore society to the White Paper.

Column: 2260



    Despite having to put the spotlight once again on the Muslim community, I believe it is timely that the White Paper was released. I say so because the various communities in Singapore have quite different perceptions regarding the JI threat. This has become quite clear from the feedback received by the Feedback Unit. In particular, over the past week, the Feedback Unit conducted three dialogue sessions with the various communities, specifically on this White Paper.

    Let me share some of the findings with the House which, I believe, are quite representative. Some people perceived that the terrorist threat to Singapore at this point in time to be quite minimal as the Government has broken the back of the JI organisation and has taken all the necessary precautions. As a result, they are more than happy to leave it to the Government to deal with the problem.

    As regards Singapore as a target for terrorist attacks, they believe that, being a hard target, the terrorist would choose other easier ones, as demonstrated by what happened when the JI carried out the October 12 bombing in Bali. To them, as long as there are easier targets around, Singapore will be safe, and will be lower down the list.

    On the other end of the scale, others think that Singapore, being an icon of modernity and being indeed a hard nut to crack, would make it all the more attractive, as the psychological impact of a successful strike would be all the more greater. After all, terrorism feeds on publicity of the greatest suffering of human beings. The more audacious the target, the higher the number of casualties, the greater is the value of the target. Most Singaporeans feel that the Government has a handle on the threat and, therefore, they do not need to be personally involved. Life goes on as per normal. If the Police and ISD do their jobs properly, then all is well. I believe the White Paper, by going into great details, will educate those who hold such views.

    Mdm Deputy Speaker, I believe we are not facing up to the truth if I do not point

Column: 2261

out that from the feedback received by the Feedback Unit, there are segments in the Muslim community who feel sympathy for the JI members. Some even expressed doubts about the Government's case against the JI. While all Muslims reject the violent means advocated by the JI brotherhood, many could not reconcile with themselves that the JI members are bad Muslims. Since Muslims are taught from young to defend themselves when they are oppressed, many Muslims felt that the JI members were just carrying out their Muslim duties when they joined the JI in the defence of Islam. Of course, in this case, they are not rising to the defence of Islam in Singapore but to the suffering of Muslims elsewhere at the oppression of the western world. Hopefully, the details of the White Paper would convince these Muslims that, indeed, JI members are misled Muslims and had been led astray by false religious teachings.

    What I would like to point out to the House, especially to Mr K Shanmugam and Mr Low Thia Khiang, is that in all the feedback collected from the Malay community, either in open and free dialogue or anonymous surveys, no one has asserted that the social and economic conditions of the Malay community in Singapore contributed to the increasing religiosity of the community. I am, in fact, very disturbed by Mr Tan Tarn How's article in the Straits Times which questions whether the Government has swept this aspect of the issue under the carpet. Yes, there are pleas from the Muslim participants in the feedback process to accept them as they are, as just another human being. But, to the credit of the Muslim community, they do not blame the society for some of their members being misled into JI.

    I understand from the exchanges between Mr Low Thia Khiang and Mr Hawazi Daipi that Mr Low is quite skilled in putting across his point. He is so skilful that he misled Mr Tan Tarn How in stating in his article that the occurrence of the JI could be attributed to the political, social and economic factors that may be making the Muslims behave as they do.

Column: 2262

I think that article is like coming out with an apology for a murderer. Instead of asking whether the upbringing of the murderer was at fault, such as whether he comes from a broken family, whether his moral education was weak, an apology is offered. The apologist looks for the presence of a defective gene in his DNA make-up, or whether the murderer was basically inclined to violence because he grew up in a poor and violent neighbourhood or he watched too much violent kungfu movies. To look for an apology for an individual might give the apologist a satisfaction in being a do-gooder. But to look for an apology for the whole community would be to lampoon the sweat and blood put in by the community and to belittle the progress made by the community - in this case, the Malay/Muslim community since Singapore's independence.

    Mdm Deputy Speaker, may I suggest that we all go and read the booklet titled Progress of the Malay Community in Singapore since 1999 which carried the Prime Minister's speech at the Malay/Muslim Organisations' Tribute to the Prime Minister's 10 Years of Leadership, dated 21st January 2001. In it, the Prime Minister grabbed the bull by the horns by answering the question, "Are the Malay Singaporeans marginalised?" directly. He looked at the progress made by the Malay community in four domains: education, occupation, income and quality of life. In every domain, the Malays have made substantial and significant progress. The Prime Minister also compared the education and economic profiles of the Singapore Malays with the Malays in Malaysia. Even though it is true that there are more Malay millionaires and more Malays holding top positions in the public and private sectors in Malaysia, overall, the Singapore Malays have fared well compared to the Malaysian Malays. Since Singapore Malays have done equally well as the Malaysian Malays, the argument that the Malay community is marginalised does not hold water.

    Earlier, Ms Indranee Rajah had also touched upon a comparison of then and now when relating the factors leading to

Column: 2263

the racial riots in 1964. She pointed out that there are many similarities. But she neglected to point out that between then and now, there are also many differences. Just in case hon. Members of the House may be misled to believe that history might repeat itself, perhaps we can look at the differences between then and now. Firstly, I think the difference is that we Singaporeans are in total charge of our own destiny. Now, there is the absence of racial enclaves in Singapore through the HDB's housing policy. Finally, the progress made by the Malay community, as indicated by the Prime Minister.

    Thus, I would urge this House not to be swayed by the arguments of the apologists in drawing conclusions about the large number of individuals as complex as a community, but to look at the cold facts and figures - facts and figures in the booklet I mentioned, and facts and figures in the White Paper on the JI terrorists.

    Given all these misconceptions and complacency and doubts, it is indeed appropriate that this White Paper is released. If we look at the profiles of the JI detainees, we will find that many of them hold good jobs with reasonable incomes and are house-owners. Those who have read the Senior Minister's memoirs would recall the episode of a bicycle owner carrying his precious possession up to his flat away from harm's way during the racial riots in 1964. This convinced Senior Minister that a stakeholder would be a better citizen, since he would prefer stability, in order to protect his stake in the nation. In this case, the JI detainees are stakeholders, yet they are prepared to give up all for a calling. Perhaps, instead of looking for reasons which moved these men into joining the JI, from the social, political and economic backgrounds of the whole community, maybe, indeed, it is a simple case of men looking for the true meaning of life. For those of us who are past 50 years of age, I would say that we are all beginning to feel the cold of the grave. We stare mortality in the eye, and have to reconcile ourselves with the fact that one of these

Column: 2264

days we will die - the strong, powerful, weak or simple persons. Some of us will have to live with it; others would seek solace in religion. I surmise that the JI detainees seek the true meaning of being human and, in so doing, were misled by the religious teachers. Those who sit down and read the White Paper with an open mind will find that this is indeed the case.

    Mdm Deputy Speaker, since its release, the White Paper is of indeed great interest to Singaporeans. It seems to fulfill a need among Singaporeans to know about the threat that prompted the arrests of close to 50 individuals under the ISA. There was a rush to buy the printed copies, and the number of attempts to access the website hit an all-time high. Unfortunately, I have received feedback that the White Paper is priced at $22 a copy. This has made it unaffordable to many in the lower income bracket to get a copy. This led to some of the individuals raising questions about the motive of the Government in setting such a high price. Since the objective of the Government in releasing the White Paper must be to disseminate the information as widely as possible, it is fair to set the copy price as low as possible. Perhaps the Government could take this into consideration in pricing future White Papers. But, of course, the pricing really did not deter those who were interested to find out more about the White Paper, because the content is widely reported in the newspapers. Thus, anyone who is interested in the content will find most of the major findings reproduced in the newspapers.

    May I now come to the content of the White Paper itself. Reading through the Paper, one can conclude that the knowledge and the expertise within the Ministry of Home Affairs regarding the JI have increased by leaps and bounds since December 2001, when the first batch of JI members was arrested. The White Paper paints the landscape of globalisation of Islamic fervour originating from Saudi Arabia. This fervour drives the Al-Qaeda movement to take on the strongest nation on earth, the United States. The White Paper also describes the dream of the

Column: 2265

Islamic movement to create a new pan-Southeast Asia state, Daulah Islamiyah Nusantara, based on Islamic values and how the local JI movement is linked to the global network. The analysis of the source of revolutionary fervour makes it very clear to the reader that unless the global Islamic revival subsides, the deviant ideology to pursue changes by violent means will always continue to influence Muslims world-wide. Singapore would be no exception. We cannot wish this rising tide away, and the world has to learn to live with it for a long time to come. As Encik Othman Haron Eusofe has said, there is really no quick fix. It is true that the arrests have disrupted the existing network, but the fundamental motive force driving the fervent Muslims to its cause will remain for a long time.

    The White Paper details how fire-brand religious teachers, like Ibrahim Maidin, identify, cultivate, recruit and control the JI members, using techniques bordering on mind-control that are reminiscent of religious cults. The use of oath of allegiance is one such example. Once converted to the cause, the JI members will stay true to the cause for a long time. After all, they truly believe that they are serving the purpose of a higher calling. I believe that since the first batch of JI members was detained in December 2001, few, if any, of them, are repentant. It does beg the question whether the authorities have a rehabilitation programme to return these detainees ultimately to the mainstream of Singapore society, given the difficult tasks ahead.

    Given the fact that the authorities have now a much more robust understanding of the motive of the JI movement and the modus operandi on how members are recruited, I would say that most Singaporeans can rest easy to know that counter-measures would be put in place to curb the spread of the deviant teachings. Confidence of the authorities in these areas has indeed increased.

    Mdm Deputy Speaker, what does this House hope to achieve in debating this motion? The Minister, in moving the

Column: 2266

motion, has touched upon many aspects. My personal list of desired outcomes is as follows.

    Firstly, this White Paper has attracted world-wide attention, in particular, among security agencies in the world. It demonstrates the competencies of our ISD. The report will serve to reassure the world that Singapore has a good grasp of the threat and takes this threat seriously. We have the will and the means to put in place long-term measures, such as restricting vehicular access to Jurong Island, despite increasing costs and greater inconvenience. This will increase investor confidence in Singapore despite it being in the midst of a turbulent region.

    The second desired outcome is the acceptance that the JI movement is a low-level, hard-to-detect secret organisation comprising many cells. Such organisations are difficult to infiltrate and difficult to exterminate. Since the threat is a long-term one, we cannot depend entirely on the authorities to eliminate the threat. Every citizen has a role to play. Every one of us must take on the responsibility to eliminate this rogue DNA from our society to prevent the cancer from taking root and spreading beyond control.

    The third desired outcome is the need of the Muslim leaders to come out loudly to reassure the rest of the community that the majority of Muslims in Singapore do not subscribe to the ideology of the JI. That Islamic values are consistent with democracy and do not impose changes through violent means. I am glad to note that in this House, most of the Malay MPs who have spoken have indeed done so. And it is also true that the Muslim leaders have in the past repeatedly stepped forward to issue such reassurance. However, perhaps the message is worth repeating, so that it could be driven into the consciousness of the rest of the community. In one of the dialogue sessions, one Muslim participant pleaded with the group, asking what sort of reassurance do the other communities need. She was particularly disturbed that there were participants who called for the Government to legislate against deviant Islamic

Column: 2267

teachings. This motion provides yet another opportunity for Muslim leaders to state clearly the condemnation of the JI terrorists.

    It is reassuring to most non-Muslim lay persons that the Muslim community has undertaken a self-regulatory role to monitor deviant teachings of religious teachers. If such teachings could be curbed, the rank of the potential recruits in the JI would be thinned.

    The fourth desired outcome is the recognition that the burden of containing this threat does not rest on the Muslim community alone. As I have said earlier, every one of us has a role to play. At the moment, the increasing religiosity of the Muslim community which finds expression in more rigid adherence with respect to attire, food and conduct towards the opposite sex, such as not shaking hands, is viewed with some anxiety by the other communities. Instead of greater integration after so many years of nationhood, this development in the Muslim community seems to lead to greater segregation and less interaction. This need not be so. I think it behoves the non-Muslims to develop greater awareness and appreciation of the Islamic culture. Every one of us should extend our hands across the racial lines to gain a better understanding of each other's customs and religious practices. You yourself, Mdm Deputy Speaker, and Mr K Shanmugam, both believe that it is important that everyone, in particular, the majority, to take this step. We should banish ignorance and eliminate fear of the unknown through knowledge. As one Muslim dialogue participant pointed out, a stricter adherence is an indication of the desire to become a better Muslim. A better Muslim makes for a better member of the community, a better citizen of the nation. This cannot be but for a better Singapore.

    Mdm Deputy Speaker, prior to the discovery of the JI movement, we all thought that racial harmony could be achieved through mutual respect and protection of each other's rights, as we have done so since independence. We

Column: 2268

were inclined to leave it to time for a common Singapore identity to emerge. There is this faith that we will gel as a nation, as a people, over time, as if the amalgamation process would take place naturally. It is like managing the health of our body. So long as we provide our body with food and water, the heart will pump the blood, the blood will nourish the various organs so that the whole body will function well. The discovery of the JI is akin to the discovery of cancer cells in our body. Left unchecked, the cancer will grow and spread, ultimately leading to death. Active treatment is called for, such as surgery, followed by chemotherapy and thereafter continuous life-long monitoring and treatment. Similarly, we no longer can let nature take its course in managing the racial harmony and social cohesion of our nation. The active participation of every stakeholder is needed. I agree with Mr K Shanmugam that now is the time for action so that our children will continue to live in peace and harmony in future.

    This particular situation is forced upon us. We Singaporeans must rise to the occasion. I am confident that together we will overcome.

CPR TRAINING FOR CIVIL DEFENCE PERSONNEL

    Mr Wong Kan Seng:

    Over the past 20 years, SCDF has worked closely with various organisations and the community to train Singaporeans in civil defence (CD) skills, including CPR. To-date, more than 260,000 people have been trained in first aid and CPR. In the last 5 years alone, some 70,000 were trained.

    Examples of SCDF's public education and training efforts include:

    a. Training members of school uniformed groups in basic CD skills, including CPR;

    b. Educating residents on CD skills through Community Safety and Security Programmes (CSSPs);

    c. Conducting courses to equip volunteers with the necessary CD skills;

    d. Conducting CD Awareness Training Programme at the Fire Stations and Satellite Fire Posts for members of the public; and

    e. Conducting Basic Cardiac Life Support Courses for members of the public at the Civil Defence Academy to equip participants with the necessary knowledge on CPR.

    The SCDF has also, over the past 2 years, introduced new initiatives to train more Singaporeans in CD skills. The CD Awareness Training Programme is now more accessible to the public as it is conducted at Fire Stations and Satellite Fire Posts, which are conveniently located in residential estates. The SCDF has also trained volunteer instructors to help train members from their own community in CD skills. Specifically on CPR skills, SCDF has developed the musical CPR programme where music is incorporated into the CPR drill to help them learn and practise their CPR skills in an interesting way.

    The SCDF also encourages and supports community-led efforts to train Singaporeans in CD skills. A good example is the CPR programme jointly run by the Boys' Brigade, Alexandra Hospital and Central Singapore CDC. More than 2,000 people have been trained under this programme.
